	<item>
		<title>The Rising Health Food Trend in China</title>
		<link>http://blog.getchee.com/?p=4146</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 03 Jan 2013 08:13:19 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chrishubbard</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.getchee.com/?p=4146</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[A new health food trend is emerging as incomes for young urban professionals in China continue to rise. Due in part to recent food related health scares such as chemically tainted milk and recycled "sewer" oil, buyers with more money are becoming more selective about their food purchases in China, choosing organic and vegetarian options over other. In this month’s Visual Trends infographic we look at other drivers of the health food trend in China as well as how food companies can address this growing trend.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-4147" alt="VisualTrends_HealthTrend_Full" src="http://blog.getchee.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/VisualTrends_HealthTrend_Full.png" width="526" height="6093" />]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>4146</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2013-01-03 04:13:19</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2013-01-03 08:13:19</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>the-rising-health-food-trend-in-china</wp:post_name>

	<item>
		<title>Fertile Retail Ground - Uniqlo Finds Incredible Growth in Philippines</title>
		<link>http://blog.getchee.com/?p=4159</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 09 Jan 2013 01:24:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.getchee.com/?p=4159</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-4161" alt="uniqlo-philippines" src="http://blog.getchee.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/uniqlo-philippines.jpg" width="526" height="227" />

Information prepared by <a title="getchee – Market insight, tools, and services to help brands in Asia." href="http://www.getchee.com/?utm_source=getchee&amp;utm_medium=newsletter&amp;utm_campaign=weekly+newsletter+january+8+2013+blog" target="_blank">getchee</a>, with sources: <a href="http://www.retailinasia.com/article/sectors/fashion/2013/01/taking-stock-philippine-market-surprises-uniqlo" target="_blank">Retail in Asia</a>, <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uniqlo" target="_blank">Wikipedia</a>

Uniqlo opened its first store in the Philippines in June 2012 in SM Mall of Asia, a waterfront site on Manila Bay. The mall is one of the world's largest, boasting a floor area of 407,000 square meters.

Going large, Uniqlo opened a massive flagship store with about 1,550 square meters, making it one of the mall's largest tenants, and entering the market with a bang.

Given the fact that Uniqlo brand recognition amongst Filipino consumers is practically non-existent according to the brand owner, the success of the new store in SM Mall has surprised and surpassed HQ expectations.

Uniqlo's Chief Operating Officer Katsumi Kubota, said their vision in the Philippines is paying off. In less than five months, the brand has opened its second store, this time on the opposite side of the town at the SM City North EDSA in Quezon City.

"The result is beyond our expectation. In terms of numbers and sales, it is remarkable. In our headquarters in Tokyo, everybody starts to talk about the Philippines," Kubota said.

The brand attributes much of its newfound success to the fact that Uniqlo's "made for all" core concept penetrates deep into the Filipino marketplace, where there tend to be large families with varying age ranges.

This "made for all" philosophy underlies the company's objective to provide casual clothing for all people regardless of age, gender, ethnicity, or any other ways that define an individual.

"Our advantage here is that there is no preconception. We tried to communicate well to local customers who we are, what we do and what we offer," Kubota said, adding this approach will continue.

<strong>Our Thoughts</strong>

We can be sure to see steady growth for the brand in the coming months. The Japanese executives revealed plans to open another 50 stores over the next 3 years, showing a true commitment to growing the Uniqlo network in the Philippines.

A key challenge now is brand communication. Over the coming months Uniqlo will no-doubt need to listen and understand how to better interact with customers and tweak business operations and product mix to best suit this new fertile market.

<a title="getchee Newsletter Archive – News for markets in China, India, and Southeast Asia." href="http://www.getchee.com/newsletter/" target="_blank">Newsletter Archive</a> | <a title="getchee Newsletter Signup - News for markets in China, India, and Southeast Asia." href="http://www.getchee.com/newsletter/newsletter-invite.html" target="_blank">Newsletter Signup</a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>The Advance of Mobile GIS Apps for Business Surveys</title>
		<link>http://blog.getchee.com/?p=4173</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 01 Jan 1970 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>johnnylin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.getchee.com/?p=4173</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Today, mobile technology is bringing us to a higher level then we’ve ever had before. It’s a huge revolution changing everything from the size of devices, battery endurance, finger touch operations, wireless internet connections, GPS, cameras and so on. As the role of a GIS user, what kinds of benefit will this revolution bring to us, and how will GIS play a role in it's impact?

<a title="Why You Should Be Using GIS for Retail" href="http://blog.getchee.com/?p=3936?utm_source=getchee&amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;utm_campaign=january%2B2013%2Bblogposts" target="_blank">+Learn about what GIS is and how it's used by retailers</a>

Let’s focus on business (intelligence). Fortunately, we have <a title="ArcGIS for Mobile | Mobile Solutions that Fit Your Enterprise" href="http://www.esri.com/software/arcgis/about/mobile-gis-for-you?utm_source=getchee&amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;utm_campaign=january%2B2013%2Bblogposts" target="_blank">GIS software</a> helping us to connect with our mobile device. There are several contributions: GIS support and data integration, efficienct survey collection and management, smart micro computer technology integration, and real-time data management.

This is my favorite one: Efficient survey collection and how it works with a mobile device.

A surveyor no longer needs to spend time on paper forms and traditional survey methods. All that's needed is to install an application kit (apple.ipa or android.apk) into a mobile device. The surveyor can quickly access the system and submit quality field data with photos. Below is a workflow that describes how easy it is to collect data and save valuable time with regard to post-survey processing.

<a href="http://blog.getchee.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/01_DataCollection.jpg"><img alt="01_DataCollection" src="http://blog.getchee.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/01_DataCollection-1024x469.jpg" width="526" height="243" /></a>

Moreover, <a title="getchee – Market insight, tools, and services to help brands in Asia." href="http://www.getchee.com?utm_source=getchee&amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;utm_campaign=january%2B2013%2Bblogposts" target="_blank">getchee</a> is able to provide customer satisfaction surveys through a mobile system for connecting with your customers to build your business. Customer satisfaction is key for the survival of any business. Finding out where customers are from, where they are currently located, what’s most important to them, and whether their needs are being satisfied are the keys to developing a strategic expansion plan that puts new stores near the right customers.

<a href="http://vimeo.com/37636293" target="_blank">+Watch a video about how Mobile Contribution uses GIS mapping</a>

Mobile devices are enriching and improve efficiency for the way we do surveys and collect data. With GIS support and data integration, we can say goodbye to the old paper surveys which tend to be the root of many headaches. It's true there can be a high price for high technology but the savings over time can help lead to business success.

<span style="color: #ff0000;"><a title="5 of the Most Common Data Headaches in Asian Emerging Markets" href="http://blog.getchee.com/?p=4200?utm_source=getchee&amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;utm_campaign=january%2B2013%2Bblogposts" target="_blank" rel="bookmark">+5 of the Most Common Data Headaches in Asian Emerging Markets</a></span>

<a title="getchee Newsletter Archive – News for markets in China, India, and Southeast Asia." href="http://www.getchee.com/newsletter/" target="_blank">Newsletter Archive</a> | <a title="getchee Newsletter Signup - News for markets in China, India, and Southeast Asia." href="http://www.getchee.com/newsletter/newsletter-invite.html" target="_blank">Newsletter Signup</a> | <a title="Send us an email." href="mailto:curious@getchee.com" target="_blank">Contact Us</a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How Big Data Is Changing Retail Market Analytics</title>
		<link>http://blog.getchee.com/?p=4176</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 01 Jan 1970 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>kennylee</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.getchee.com/?p=4176</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="text-align: left;"><img class="wp-image-4308" alt="finger print iris scan" src="http://blog.getchee.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/4420936023_06ddf1dbdf.jpg" width="526" height="362" />Photo Credit: <a title="Finger Print Iris Scan" href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/48326810@N08/4420936023/" target="_blank">tampaempire</a></p>
<strong><span style="color: #888888;">Big Data Offers Big Opportunities</span></strong>

<span style="font-size: 13px;">Big data has become a core competitive advantage in nearly every industry as successful companies are mining their data for information that might turn a series of seemingly random numbers and information into solid-gold profits. </span><span style="font-size: 13px;">So, what does the term "big data" really mean? Big data is just all the data that is generated and comes into the realm of companies today. And it's growing.</span>

IBM, one of the leading players in this emerging space, estimates that 2.5 quintillion bytes of data are created every day from a variety of sources, including sensors, social media and billions of mobile devices around the world, making it difficult for businesses to navigate and analyze it to improve competitiveness, efficiency and profitability. IDC estimates the market for big data technology and services will grow at an annual rate of nearly 40 percent to reach $16.9 billion by 2015. Moreover, every month people send 1 billion Tweets and post 30 billion messages on Facebook. Meanwhile, more than 1 trillion mobile devices are in use today and mobile commerce is expected to reach $31 billion by 2016.

<a title="5 of the Most Common Data Headaches in Asian Emerging Markets" href="http://blog.getchee.com/?p=4200?utm_source=getchee&amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;utm_campaign=january%2B2013%2Bblogposts" target="_blank">+Read about 5 of the most common data headaches in Asian emerging markets</a>

<strong><span style="color: #888888;">Big Data for the Retail Market</span></strong>

To apply big data to the retail market, in which we seek to draw actionable inferences from customers’ shopping behavior, we must first account for relevant factors like store location quality, employees in the store, layout and store merchandising, staffing schedules, complete detail on actual sales, and surprisingly... even the weather. Input sources can include video cameras, Wi-Fi tracking tags, RFID, and other in-store systems like those for Point-of-Sale (POS), staffing, mobile APP checking in to places and events.

If you are providing Wi-Fi to retail shoppers, you can show them the most relevant websites, search terms, product review sites, and even product price points at any given time. You can collect a mountain of data across a highly distributed environment (think thousands of retail stores). This data can then be sifted and processed to presents trends in a meaningful way so that management can take intelligent action. Just a few years ago this would have been an impossible system to build, or massively expensive at the very least.

Via new data sources, retailers can gain a precise, factual understanding of how shoppers move around their stores – where they go, in what order, how long they stay, when they come to the store, and how all of these questions map to actual sales. Retailers have optimized store layouts, fixtures, staffing, and even product offerings based on what they learned.

<a title="How is mobile changing retail?" href="http://blog.getchee.com/?p=4070?utm_source=getchee&amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;utm_campaign=january%2B2013%2Bblogposts" target="_blank">+View an infographic about how Mobile technology is changing retail trends</a>

<strong><span style="color: #888888;"> Types of Big Data Analytics in Retail</span></strong>

We analyzed the typical retailers and found some interesting patterns of how raw data is being converted into signals and actions. Most of the retail analytics and big data retailers tend to cluster around the following areas:

-Customer Analytics
-Merchandizing KPIs
-Store Operations Analytics
-Vendor and SKU Management Scorecards
-Marketing Analytics
-Returns, Fraud and Loss Prevention Analytics

<a title="getchee – Estimate Market Potential &amp; Perform a Competitor Analysis" href="http://www.getchee.com/services/network-optimization-study.html?utm_source=getchee&amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;utm_campaign=january%2B2013%2Bblogposts" target="_blank">+Learn how big data is used to optimize retail networks</a>

<strong><span style="color: #888888;"><span style="font-size: 13px;">Benefits of Big Data Analytics in the Retail Market</span></span></strong>

A McKinsey study released in May 2011 stated that, by using big data to the fullest, retailers stood to increase their operating margins by up to 60%, <span style="font-size: 13px;">this is a pretty powerful weapon in a highly competitive space like retail. The key benefits of using big data analytics in the retail market include:</span>

<span style="font-size: 13px;">-Big data can unlock significant value by making information transparent and usable at much higher frequency.</span>

-<span style="font-size: 13px;">As organizations create and store more transactional data in digital form, they can collect more accurate and detailed performance information on everything from product inventories to sick days, and therefore expose variability and boost performance. Leading companies are using data collection and analysis to conduct controlled experiments to make better management decisions; others are using data for basic low-frequency forecasting to high-frequency nowcasting to adjust their business levers just in time.</span>

-<span style="font-size: 13px;">Big data allows ever-narrower segmentation of customers and therefore much more precisely tailored products or services.</span>

-<span style="font-size: 13px;">Big data analytics can substantially improve decision-making.</span>

-<span style="font-size: 13px;">Big data can be used to improve the development of the next generation of products and services. For instance, manufacturers are using data obtained from sensors embedded in products to create innovative after-sales service offerings such as proactive maintenance.</span>

<a title="getchee – Demographic &amp; Market Segmentation Data for Asian Markets" href="http://www.getchee.com/data/data-overview.html?utm_source=getchee&amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;utm_campaign=january%2B2013%2Bblogposts" target="_blank">+Learn more about how getchee uses big data</a>

<a title="getchee Newsletter Archive – News for markets in China, India, and Southeast Asia." href="http://www.getchee.com/newsletter/" target="_blank">Newsletter Archive</a> | <a title="getchee Newsletter Signup - News for markets in China, India, and Southeast Asia." href="http://www.getchee.com/newsletter/newsletter-invite.html" target="_blank">Newsletter Signup</a> | <a title="Send us an email." href="mailto:curious@getchee.com" target="_blank">Contact Us</a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Taiwan vs China, the good the bad and the mean</title>
		<link>http://blog.getchee.com/?p=4185</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 01 Jan 1970 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>georgemassey</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.getchee.com/?p=4185</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[taiwan is way cooler than China]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>4185</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2013-01-10 23:08:27</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>0000-00-00 00:00:00</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>draft</wp:status>

	<item>
		<title>Eyes on Vietnam - Foreign &amp; Domestic Investment Heating up in 2013</title>
		<link>http://blog.getchee.com/?p=4189</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 16 Jan 2013 01:28:24 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.getchee.com/?p=4189</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-4190" alt="hanoi-shopping-mall" src="http://blog.getchee.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/hanoi-shopping-mall1.jpg" width="526" height="227" />

Information prepared by <a title="getchee – Market insight, tools, and services to help brands in Asia." href="http://www.getchee.com/?utm_source=getchee&amp;utm_medium=newsletter&amp;utm_campaign=weekly+newsletter+january+15+2013+blog" target="_blank">getchee</a>, with sources: <a href="http://vietnamnews.vn/Economy/234928/retail-industry-draws-investors.html" target="_blank">Viet Nam News</a>, <a href="http://business.blogs.cnn.com/2010/06/09/vietnam-the-new-china/" target="_blank">CNN Business 360</a>

2013 may be a landslide year for Vietnam's retail market growth. With a population of 90 million people and growing, Vietnam shows clear signs that doors are open to multinational and domestic companies for investment and expansion opportunities.

Vietnam has seen 10 years of average annual growth of about 7 percent. This number is projected to grow in the coming years as infrastructure is strengthened and market entry becomes easier.

Just this month Starbucks announced its plans to open a store in Ho Chi Minh City as part of its strategy to expand across Asia, and plans to add more shops throughout the country. A very ambitious goal considering Vietnam's established coffee drinking culture adopted from the French.

The middle-class, much like China, is really beginning to pull apart and stand out on its own. With newfound financial flexibility and ambitions, the middle-class will be the focus target for retailers.

Andrew Stevens, CNN World Business Today Anchor, says, "To say Vietnam is open for business is an understatement – and this Southeast Asian growing powerhouse is deadly serious about drawing foreign business."

He goes on to say that Prime Minister Nguyen Tan Dung is spending considerable time chatting up the opportunities. He wants Vietnam to be Asia’s manufacturing base of choice after China. Samsung and Canon are both investing heavily in electronics manufacturing and service bases.

<strong>Our Thoughts</strong>

These are really exciting times as Vietnam seems to be experiencing the growth and development pattern that China began years ago (and still is).

It's not only western retailers that have their eyes on Vietnam, supermarket/hypermarket brands Big C, Metro, Lotte Mart, and S.Mart have all announced plans for heavy investment and expansion throughout the market.

Today there are about 636 supermarkets, 120 shopping centers, and more than 1,000 convenience stores, but experts think this nowhere near reaches market demand.

It's estimated that modern retail currently accounts for only about 20 percent of the country's potential. According to the Association of Viet Nam Retailers general secretary Dinh Thi My Loan, that percentage will likely grow to 45 percent in the next 7 years.

Reasons for choosing Vietnam are fairly simple.

It's cheaper (labor costs are roughly 60 percent of China's), its geographic location allows it to reach many neighboring markets, there's little state intervention, and it's growing middle-class will represent a valid consumer target for retailers hoping to capture new potential.

<a title="getchee Newsletter Archive – News for markets in China, India, and Southeast Asia." href="http://www.getchee.com/newsletter/" target="_blank">Newsletter Archive</a> | <a title="getchee Newsletter Signup - News for markets in China, India, and Southeast Asia." href="http://www.getchee.com/newsletter/newsletter-invite.html" target="_blank">Newsletter Signup</a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="apparel-merchandise"><![CDATA[Apparel &amp; Merchandise]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="food-beverage"><![CDATA[Food &amp; Beverage]]></category>

		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="vietnam"><![CDATA[vietnam]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="vietnam-2"><![CDATA[Vietnam]]></category>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[9]]></wp:meta_value>

			<wp:meta_key>_aioseop_description</wp:meta_key>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>5 of the Most Common Data Headaches in Asian Emerging Markets</title>
		<link>http://blog.getchee.com/?p=4200</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 07 Feb 2013 10:08:15 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>samho</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.getchee.com/?p=4200</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="text-align: left;"><img class="wp-image-4290" alt="5337504157_cd964ff638" src="http://blog.getchee.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/5337504157_cd964ff638.jpg" width="525" height="390" />Photo Credit: <a title="SOCIALly overNETWORKed" href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/12187843@N07/5337504157/" target="_blank">ViaMoi</a></p>
We all know that interest in <a title="What is big data?" href="http://strata.oreilly.com/2012/01/what-is-big-data.html" target="_blank">big data</a> is exploding, web mapping applications are become more and more critical for business decisions, and data service companies like <a title="getchee – Market insight, tools, and services to help brands in Asia." href="http://www.getchee.com?utm_source=getchee&amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;utm_campaign=january%2B2013%2Bblogposts" target="_blank">getchee</a> are seeing a surge in spatial data request, especially for Asian countries. However, as data requests grow, many common misunderstandings about Asian data consistently surface, as users of this data tend to apply the same data standards they see being used in the U.S. or European countries. Here are some of the most common issues that we often face in the Asian data market:

<strong><span style="color: #808080;">1. Where is the block group data?</span></strong>

There is no block group data available in most Asian emerging markets except for a few more developed regions like Japan or  Hong Kong. One of the reasons for this is that the data granularity tends to be much poorer than it is in the U.S. or Europe countries. The most common boundary for general population data would be by district, which is more granular than city data in most Asian countries. You may be able to collect some population data that is smaller than a district size, which we would call a neighborhood, but the quality will vary between countries. Sometimes, the only data available will be at a city level.

<a title="getchee – Demographic &amp; Market Segmentation Data for Asian Markets" href="http://www.getchee.com/data/data-overview.html?utm_source=getchee&amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;utm_campaign=january%2B2013%2Bblogposts#demographic_segments" target="_blank">+See how getchee creates its demographic segments using Asian data</a>

<span style="color: #808080;"><strong>2. Why is there no spending behavior data available?</strong></span>

The available general demographic data items for Asian countries are commonly limited. The most popular data is basic population with age or education segments only. Unfortunately, the data of consumer spending behavior is typically not available either. Governments normally hold some household income or expenditure statistics by sampling, but it is not always available for each city and the published unit is often by city only.

<span style="color: #808080;"><strong>3. Isn't there a single source for official demographic data?</strong></span>

Not yet, unfortunately. The central government statistics in Asia aren't always complete, and occasionally, you can even find different items (or, even different figures) published within the local governments' official data. This can create obvious validation problems. The good news is that there are more and more reliable companies contracted by Asian governments to publish the official demographic data. Therefore, you don't always need to deal with the often exasperating administration process involved with collecting official data. And keep in mind that data is not always available electronically in Asia either.

<a title="getchee – Demographic &amp; Market Segmentation Data for Asian Markets" href="http://www.getchee.com/data/data-overview.html?utm_source=getchee&amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;utm_campaign=january%2B2013%2Bblogposts" target="_blank">+Explore Asian data packages available from getchee</a>

<span style="color: #808080;"><strong>4. I need historic data for comparison.</strong></span>

Time trend data is always useful for any kind of business analysis, and this type of data is fast improving throughout Asia as record keeping methods improve as well. However, you may find that this type of data and tracing units might not be consistent at all times. In another words, although doing a time trend analysis is possible, you should be prepared to use a variety of methods to perform it correctly.

<span style="color: #808080;"><strong>5. I cannot match my demographics table with the map.</strong></span>

Generally speaking, most available demographic data goes with the political/administration boundary of the country it's retrieved from. So collecting the city and district boundary maps will always be helpful. However, the sub-city boundary data is not always available. Sometimes these boundaries aren't consistant across data even when referencing the same area. This sort of problem is most common for neighborhood boundary maps. Government demographics are usually by list and table only, with no actual map to go with it, so many businesses find themselves searching for map builders or mapping software to help them better digest their data.

<a title="getchee – GIS Mapping Software, Site Selection &amp; Network Optimization" href="http://www.getchee.com/products/kiwi-overview.html?utm_source=getchee&amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;utm_campaign=january%2B2013%2Bblogposts" target="_blank">+Learn how Kiwi can help businesses map out data</a>

<a title="getchee Newsletter Archive – News for markets in China, India, and Southeast Asia." href="http://www.getchee.com/newsletter/" target="_blank">Newsletter Archive</a> | <a title="getchee Newsletter Signup - News for markets in China, India, and Southeast Asia." href="http://www.getchee.com/newsletter/newsletter-invite.html" target="_blank">Newsletter Signup</a> | <a title="Send us an email." href="mailto:curious@getchee.com" target="_blank">Contact Us</a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>4200</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2013-02-07 06:08:15</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2013-02-07 10:08:15</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>5-of-the-most-common-data-headaches-in-asian-emerging-markets</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="apparel-2"><![CDATA[Apparel]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="banking"><![CDATA[Banking]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="big-data"><![CDATA[big data]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="consumer-data"><![CDATA[consumer data]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="data-visualization-and-analysis"><![CDATA[data visualization and analysis]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="demographic-and-market-data"><![CDATA[demographic and market data]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="emerging-markets"><![CDATA[emerging markets]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="food-beverage"><![CDATA[Food &amp; Beverage]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[9]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_thumbnail_id</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[4290]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_aioseop_title</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[5 of the Most Common Data Headaches in Asian Emerging Markets]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_aioseop_description</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Many misunderstandings about Asian data consistently surface, as users of this data tend to apply the same data standards used in the U.S. or Europe.]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_aioseop_keywords</wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Brick &amp; Mortar - Lenovo Aims to Greatly Increase Its Store Presence in Asia</title>
		<link>http://blog.getchee.com/?p=4203</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 23 Jan 2013 02:36:38 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.getchee.com/?p=4203</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-4204" alt="lenovo-store" src="http://blog.getchee.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/lenovo-store.jpg" width="526" height="227" />

Information prepared by <a title="getchee – Market insight, tools, and services to help brands in Asia." href="http://www.getchee.com/?utm_source=getchee&amp;utm_medium=newsletter&amp;utm_campaign=weekly+newsletter+january+22+2013+blog" target="_blank">getchee</a>, with sources: <a href="http://www.digitimes.com/news/a20120326PD210.html" target="_blank">DigiTimes</a>, <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lenovo#Emerging_markets" target="_blank">Wikipedia</a>

In a time when more and more retailers are focusing on online and mobile platforms to increase turnover, many retailers are beginning to refocus effort into building better brick and mortar locations that enhance experience. This is what Lenovo is set on accomplishing over the next few years in Asia.

Lenovo currently has some own-brand stores throughout Asia, but plans to greatly increase the number to about 1,000 throughout the region.

Perhaps largely influenced by Apple's highly successful own-brand stores, Lenovo hopes to develop better brand awareness through brick and mortar locations.

Lenovo branded flagship and support stores may be just what the computer manufacturer needs to help augment online sales, build better customer confidence, and increase the quality of experience.

Working towards a more established 'brick and click' business model, much the same as Apple has done over previous years, Lenovo feels a physical store presence is important in remaining dominant in the PC market.

There are of course large inherent risks that come bundled with any physical retail network: rising costs of operations, rapid shifts in consumer behavior, and increased competition to name a few.

<strong>Our Thoughts</strong>

No doubt a brick and mortar presence is absolutely still needed to help establish consumer confidence and promote the brand. Choosing the right model to roll out new stores in Asia can be tricky.

Although the investment to open flagship stores and service centers would be considerable, Lenovo has much to gain by doing so.

If the brand focuses on improving the quality of service and experience through flagship stores where customers can touch, feel, and play with Lenovo products, they'll be on the right track.

Some level of flagship centers and satellite support stores will be needed to increase brand visibility and increase customer confidence.

<a title="getchee Newsletter Archive – News for markets in China, India, and Southeast Asia." href="http://www.getchee.com/newsletter/" target="_blank">Newsletter Archive</a> | <a title="getchee Newsletter Signup - News for markets in China, India, and Southeast Asia." href="http://www.getchee.com/newsletter/newsletter-invite.html" target="_blank">Newsletter Signup</a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Everything You Need to Know about Trade Zones</title>
		<link>http://blog.getchee.com/?p=4223</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 29 Jan 2013 03:00:52 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>chrishubbard</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.getchee.com/?p=4223</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Successful businesses know that the secret to finding good locations is understanding how trade zones work. In this month’s Visual Trends infographic we take a look at what makes a trade zone, why they are important, and how businesses can create them. A trade zone is simply a geographic area that contains a high density of retail, commercial, or financial infrastructure. They are areas that consumers are willing to travel to for work, shopping, or entertainment.

Generally speaking, major retailers or key anchors (malls, department stores, and hypermarkets) are the destination sites that smaller retailers and food shops cluster around.

<a href="https://vimeo.com/54073073" target="_blank">Watch our trade zone video as well to learn more about trade zones from the getchee team.</a>

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-4224" alt="VisualTrends_TradeZones_Final" src="http://blog.getchee.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/VisualTrends_TradeZones_Final.png" width="526" height="4626" />]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>4223</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2013-01-28 23:00:52</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2013-01-29 03:00:52</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>everything-you-need-to-know-about-trade-zones</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="apparel-2"><![CDATA[Apparel]]></category>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Is it time to stop caring about how many stores you have in China?</title>
		<link>http://blog.getchee.com/?p=4237</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 01 Jan 1970 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>jamesgrigsby</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.getchee.com/?p=4237</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="text-align: left;"><img class="size-full wp-image-4323" alt="chinastreet" src="http://blog.getchee.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/chinastreet.jpg" width="525" height="352" />Photo Credit: <a title="Asia | Macau: Rua da Felicidade" href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/36668777@N07/4095808409/" target="_blank">Vu Pham</a></p>
<a title="getchee – Market insight, tools, and services to help brands in Asia." href="http://www.getchee.com/?utm_source=getchee&amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;utm_campaign=january%2B2013%2Bblogposts" target="_blank">getchee</a> has been working in China for over 10 years. In the early part of the last decade, store development managers saw a blue sky market with strong potential no matter where they opened a new store. I clearly remember one store network manager for a major auto company describing potential in China to be “like a watermelon -- no matter how you slice it, you always get a juicy piece.”  As the decade wore on, this build-it-and-they-will-come approach to network development started showing signs of trouble. Our observations of the marketplace and recent work with <a title="getchee – Retail &amp; Bank Data Services for Leading Brands" href="http://www.getchee.com/about/our-clients.html?utm_source=getchee&amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;utm_campaign=january%2B2013%2Bblogposts" target="_blank">clients</a> show that retail brands are starting to place much more emphasis on per-store productivity by putting the right store format in the right location.

<a title="getchee – Retail &amp; Bank Data Services for Leading Brands" href="http://www.getchee.com/industry/merchandise-n-apparel.html?utm_source=getchee&amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;utm_campaign=january%2B2013%2Bblogposts" target="_blank">+Learn how getchee addresses some of the common problems retailers face in China</a>

For many retail brands, the amount of stores you had in China used to be the headlining statement on success in China. But in mature markets it can be difficult to find information on the number of stores (try a web search for “number of KFC stores” and you will quickly learn that there are about 5,000 KFCs in China, but you won't easily find out how many there are in the US). And for many sectors, China is rapidly maturing.

Although trumpeting a big store count is not surprising -- China is a big market and brands want to show that they have a big network -- but as the global economy slows, competitors grow, and Chinese consumers become more sophisticated, it can be a distraction to focus too heavily on store number only. Moreover, for apparel and other durable consumer goods, rapid expansion in store count may be a sign that management may not have a good handle on driving sales through existing stores.

<a title="getchee – Estimate Market Potential &amp; Perform a Competitor Analysis" href="http://www.getchee.com/services/network-optimization-study.html?utm_source=getchee&amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;utm_campaign=january%2B2013%2Bblogposts" target="_blank">+See how retailers can optimize their networks across Asia</a>

There are many signs that a market is maturing, but a clear one is certainly the rise in importance of tracking same-store sales. This metric is taking great prominence which is a change from the past. In November last year, Yum!’s New York listed stock price fell 10% when the company announced that KFC same store sales would grow by only 6% in 2012. Yes I know, strange to use the word “only” here, but in 2011, same store sales for KFC in China was 20%, and the overall retail market in China grew around 13%.

So when thinking about a retail store network, the question needs to be one of productivity. Sales per store, or even better, sales per square meter. This is, of course, not a surprise and many brand owners have made the shift from “outsourcing” product distribution through partners  to taking retail sales operations back in house. Moves by Esprit and Burberry in the past few years are some of the biggest examples of this. More recent entrants into China such as Carl’s Jr. are also looking for much more control over their points of sale.

<a title="How Does Burberry Stack Up to China’s Retail Market Potential?" href="http://blog.getchee.com/?p=3632?utm_source=getchee&amp;utm_medium=blog&amp;utm_campaign=january%2B2013%2Bblogposts" target="_blank">+See how Burberry's store counts change with market potential levels across China</a>

There are many factors of retail operations that drive productivity, starting way up the value chain with brand image and product quality. As you move closer to the point of sale, however, the question of store location and proper store network management take a very prominent role in impacting same-store sales.

<a title="getchee Newsletter Archive – News for markets in China, India, and Southeast Asia." href="http://www.getchee.com/newsletter/" target="_blank">Newsletter Archive</a> | <a title="getchee Newsletter Signup - News for markets in China, India, and Southeast Asia." href="http://www.getchee.com/newsletter/newsletter-invite.html" target="_blank">Newsletter Signup</a> | <a title="Send us an email." href="mailto:curious@getchee.com" target="_blank">Contact Us</a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>4237</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2013-02-06 02:56:35</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>0000-00-00 00:00:00</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>draft</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="apparel-merchandise"><![CDATA[Apparel &amp; Merchandise]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="apparel-and-merchandise"><![CDATA[apparel and merchandise]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="burberry"><![CDATA[burberry]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="carls-jr"><![CDATA[carl's jr.]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="china"><![CDATA[China]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="china-retail-trends"><![CDATA[china retail trends]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="doing-business-in-china-2"><![CDATA[doing business in china]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="food-beverage"><![CDATA[Food &amp; Beverage]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="kfc"><![CDATA[kfc]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="market-potential"><![CDATA[Market Potential]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="site-selection"><![CDATA[site selection]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="store-network-optimization"><![CDATA[store network optimization]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="yum"><![CDATA[yum!]]></category>

		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_aioseop_description</wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>

	<item>
		<title>Which of the following Circle K stores in Hong Kong are located in a profitable location</title>
		<link>http://blog.getchee.com/?p=4391</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 01 Feb 2013 08:13:18 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>howardhsiao</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.getchee.com/?p=4391</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_4392" align="alignnone" width="300"]<a href="http://blog.getchee.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/circle-K.png"><img class="size-medium wp-image-4392" alt="circle k hk" src="http://blog.getchee.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/circle-K-300x157.png" width="300" height="157" /></a> circle k hk[/caption]]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>4391</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2013-02-01 04:13:18</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2013-02-01 08:13:18</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>which-of-the-following-circle-k-stores-in-hong-kong-are-located-in-a-profitable-location</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>private</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="gis-software-tools"><![CDATA[GIS Software Tools]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[9]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Doors Wide Open - India&#039;s Economic Reforms Open Doors to Retailers</title>
		<link>http://blog.getchee.com/?p=4405</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 06 Feb 2013 01:41:03 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.getchee.com/?p=4405</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-4410" alt="india-opens-doors" src="http://blog.getchee.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/india-opens-doors1.jpg" width="526" height="227" />

Information prepared by <a title="getchee – Market insight, tools, and services to help brands in Asia." href="http://www.getchee.com/?utm_source=getchee&amp;utm_medium=newsletter&amp;utm_campaign=weekly+newsletter+february+5+2013+blog" target="_blank">getchee</a>, with sources: <a href="http://india.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/09/14/india-opens-door-to-foreign-investment/" target="_blank">The New York Times</a>, <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Retailing_in_India" target="_blank">Wikipedia</a>

After two days of intense debate last September, Parliament voted down a measure prohibiting large foreign retailers who carry multiple brands, like Wal-Mart, from entering the country.

Well this is pretty great news for big box retailers that have long had their eyes on the Indian market.

The government hopes that this new legislature will stimulate a new economic boom in India, where once-brisk growth has slowed in recent years. They hope these new laws will benefit the rural economy and farmers, who should get better prices for products they produce. Local retailers aren't so optimistic.

The Prime Minister tried to assure small retailers’ fears in late September, by saying that they “had nothing to fear from the impending arrival of giant Western retailers like Wal-Mart or Carrefour because there was a place for everyone, large or small, in a growing economy.”

India's younger generation appear open and eager to try foreign brands and shopping experiences according to Vikas Bajaj, former correspondent for The Times in Mumbai, India.

About half of India's 1.2 billion people are under the age of 25. How will the sudden influx of foreign multinationals effect this younger generation?

<strong>Our Thoughts</strong>

This reform is one that will affect the lives and livelihoods of the vast majority of Indian people. It will change consumers, farmers, traders, and retailers in the form of family-run kirana shops, or grocery stores, not to mention employment opportunities.

It's a big deal!

Although the legislature at the federal level has passed, each state government in India will be allowed to decide whether to open its doors to FDI or not. In any case, the path to India is now clearer than ever in the past for large multinational retailers.

No doubt there's a tremendous amount of retail potential in key cities and key trade zones, but capitalizing on it is going to be a tricky puzzle.

Hypermarkets and big box retailers, like Wal-Mart and Carrefour, will really have their hands full. Local partners will be critical in helping establish the infrastructure needed to support these retailers, and help to promote brand visibility into the future.

These giants will need accurate market planning data and analytics to help them make better site selection, assortment, and logistics decisions.

<a title="getchee Newsletter Archive – News for markets in China, India, and Southeast Asia." href="http://www.getchee.com/newsletter/" target="_blank">Newsletter Archive</a> | <a title="getchee Newsletter Signup - News for markets in China, India, and Southeast Asia." href="http://www.getchee.com/newsletter/newsletter-invite.html" target="_blank">Newsletter Signup</a> | <a title="Send us an email." href="mailto:curious@getchee.com" target="_blank">Contact Us</a>]]></content:encoded>
